sen.j: 明治（めいじ）は、日本の元号の一つ。
sen.e: Meiji is an era name of Japan.
Meiji is the name of an era in Japan.
Meiji is the name of an era in Japan.

sen.j: 慶応の後、大正の前。
sen.e: Meiji was an era after Keio and before Taisho.
Meiji is the era after Keio and before Taisho.
Meiji is the era after Keio and before Taisho.

sen.j: 明治元年1月1日 (旧暦)（1868年1月25日）から明治45年（大正元年、1912年）7月30日までの期間を指す。
sen.e: The Meiji era is the period between January 1 of the first year of the Meiji era (or January 25, 1868 by the solar calendar) and July 30 of the 45th year of Meiji or 1912.
The Meiji era is the period between January 1 of the first year of the Meiji era (or January 25, 1868 by the solar calendar) and July 30 of the 45th year of Meiji or 1912.

sen.j: 明治天皇在位期間とほぼ一致する。
sen.e: That period approximately coincided with the reign of Emperor Meiji.
This period coincided approximately with the reign of Emperor Meiji.

sen.j: ただし、実際に改元の詔書が出されたのは慶応4年9月8日 (旧暦)（1868年10月23日）で、同年1月1日に遡って明治元年とすると定めた。
sen.e: Shosho (an imperial edict) was actually issued to change the era name on September 8 of the 4th year of Keio (October 23, 1868) but it was decided that January 1 of that year (January 25, 1868) be made the first year of Meiji retroactively.

tit.cmt: 文頭のみ大文字にしました。

sen.j: 慶応4年9月8日 (旧暦)（グレゴリオ暦1868年10月23日）
sen.e: October 23, 1868

sen.j: - 明治天皇の即位による代始改元。
sen.e: - The era name was changed due to the accession of Emperor Meiji to the throne.
- The era name was changed due to the accession of Emperor Meiji to the throne.

sen.j: ただし、改元の詔書には「改慶應四年爲明治元年」（慶応4年を改めて、明治元年となす）とあり、改元が年の呼称を改めるということから、1月1日 (旧暦)（グレゴリオ暦1868年1月25日）に遡って適用された。
sen.e: The imperial edict for the change of era name, however, read, 'The fourth year of Keio shall be amended to become the first year of Meiji,' whereby, accordingly, the change of era name took effect retroactive to January 1of that year (by the lunar calendar) (or January 25, 1868 by the Gregorian calendar).

The imperial edict for the change of era name, however, read, 'The fourth year of Keio shall be amended to become the first year of Meiji,' whereby, accordingly, the change of era name took effect retroactively to January 1of that year (by the lunar calendar) (or January 25, 1868 by the Gregorian calendar).

sen.j: 法的には慶応4年1月1日より明治元年となる。
sen.e: Technically, the Meiji era began on January 1 of the 4th year of the Keio era.
Technically, the Meiji era began on January 1 of the 4th year of the Keio era.

sen.j: 7月30日（にグレゴリオ暦を施行）
sen.e: July 30 (the day that the Gregorian calendar came into effect)

sen.j: - 明治天皇崩御、大正天皇践祚により、大正に改元。
sen.e: - Emperor Meiji passed away and the era name was changed to Tisho with accession of Emperor Taisho to the throne.
- Emperor Meiji passed away and the era name was changed to Tisho with the accession of Emperor Taisho to the throne.
Emperor Meiji passed away and the era name was changed to Taisho with the accession of Emperor Taisho to the throne.
sen.cmt: ハイフン削除しました。スペル修正しました。

sen.j: 同日施行され、大正元年7月30日となった。
sen.e: The change of era name came into effect on the same day that Emperor Meiji died whereby it became July 30 of the first year of the Taisho era.
The change of era name came into effect on the same day that Emperor Meiji died whereby it became July 30 of the first year of the Taisho era.

sen.j: 『易経』の「聖人南面而聴天下、嚮明而治」より。
sen.e: Meiji was named after the clause in I Ching (The Book of Changes), 'Looking to south, the saint listens to the world and, facing towards light, he governs.'
Meiji was named after the clause in I Ching (The Book of Changes), 'Looking to south, the saint listens to the world and, facing towards light, he governs.'
Meiji was named after the clause in I Ching (The Book of Changes), 'Looking to south, the saint listens to the world and, facing towards light, he governs.'

sen.j: 「聖人南面して天下を聴き、明に嚮いて治む」というこの言葉は、過去の改元の際に江戸時代だけで8回、計10回候補として勘案されているが、通算にして11度目にして採用された。
sen.e: This phrase reading, 'Looking to south, the saint listens to the country and, facing towards light, he governs' had been considered as a prospect 10 times in total including 8 times during the Edo Period in the past when era names were changed and it was finally selected on the eleventh nomination.

sen.j: 同時に一世一元の詔も併せて出され、在位中の改元は行わないものとした。
sen.e: The imperial edict prescribing the system of issei-ichigen (one reign, one era) was issued in conjunction with the new era name taking effect meaning that no era names would change during the reign of an emperor.

The imperial edict prescribing the system of issei-ichigen (one reign, one era) was issued in conjunction with the new era name taking effect, meaning that no era names would change during the reign of an emperor.

sen.j: 越前藩松平慶永らが勘案した文面を籤としたものから、明治天皇自らが宮中賢所にて抽選したものだとされている。
sen.e: It is believed that, in Kashiko Dokoro (Palace Sanctuary), Emperor Meiji drew for the new era name which was among additional options that had been considered by some officials such as Yoshinaga MATSUDAIRA of the Echizen Clan.

It is believed that, in Kashiko Dokoro (Palace Sanctuary), Emperor Meiji drew for the new era name, one which was among some additional options that had been considered by officials such as Yoshinaga MATSUDAIRA of the Echizen Clan.

sen.j: 明治天皇が即位、新政府は天皇を中心とした新しい国家体制を築くことを目指し、新たに江戸を東京と改め、天皇が東京に行幸してここを日本の新しい政治の中心にすえた（東京奠都を参照）。
sen.e: With Emperor Meiji's accession to the throne, as part of their effort to build national polity with the emperor being the heart of it, the new government renamed Edo to Tokyo where the emperor visited to proclaim that city to be the new political center of Japan (See Tokyo Tento (transfer of the national capital to Tokyo).

With Emperor Meiji's accession to the throne, as part of their effort to build a national government centered around the emperor, the new government renamed Edo to Tokyo where the emperor visited to proclaim that city to be the new political center of Japan (See Tokyo Tento (transfer of the national capital to Tokyo).

With Emperor Meiji's accession to the throne, as part of their effort to build a national government centered around the emperor, the new government renamed Edo to Tokyo where the emperor visited to proclaim that city to be the new political center of Japan (See Tokyo Tento (transfer of the national capital to Tokyo)).

sen.j: 尊皇思想に基づき、天皇は親政を行い人民を直接統治するとしたが、政治体制は大日本帝国憲法（明治憲法）が制定されるまで、様々に変化した。
sen.e: In accordance with the pro-Emperor principles, the Government rule of a state by the direct administration of the Emperor took effect but the political system underwent numerous changes before the Constitution of the Empire of Japan (the Meiji Constitution) was enacted.

In accordance with the pro-Emperor principles, the Government rule of a state by the direct administration of the Emperor took effect but the political system underwent numerous changes before the Constitution of the Empire of Japan (the Meiji Constitution) was enacted.

In accordance with the pro-Emperor principles, the Government rule of a state by the direct administration of the Emperor took effect but the political system underwent numerous changes before the Constitution of the Empire of Japan (the Meiji Constitution) was enacted.

sen.j: 中国明朝を真似て一世一元制を定めた。
sen.e: The one reign, one era system modeled after the Ming Dynasty of China was established.
The one reign, one era system modeled after the Ming Dynasty of China was established.
The one reign, one era system modeled after the Ming Dynasty of China was established.

sen.j: 天皇の名を元号とし、それまでの陰陽道的改元を廃止した。
sen.e: The name of the emperor was to be also the era name thereby abolishing the previous practice of changing the name of an era based on Onmyodo (way of Yin and Yang; occult divination system based on the Taoist theory of the five elements).

The name of the emperor was to be also the era name thereby abolishing the previous practice of changing the name of an era based on Onmyodo (way of Yin and Yang; occult divination system based on the Taoist theory of the five elements).

sen.j: 慶応3年（1867年）江戸幕府15代将軍・徳川慶喜が、朝廷に大政奉還を行なった。
sen.e: In 1867, Yoshinobu TOKUGAWA, the 15th Shogun of the Edo bakufu (Japanese feudal government headed by a shogun) transferred power back to the Emperor.
In 1867, Yoshinobu TOKUGAWA, the 15th Shogun of the Edo bakufu (Japanese feudal government headed by a shogun) transferred power back to the Emperor.

sen.j: これにより、朝廷は王政復古 (日本)を宣言。
sen.e: The Imperial Court, herewith, proclaimed the Restoration of Imperial Rule (Japan).
The Imperial Court, herewith, proclaimed the Restoration of Imperial Rule (Japan).
The Imperial Court, herewith, proclaimed the Restoration of Imperial Rule (Japan).

sen.j: 討幕派と旧幕府勢力による戊辰戦争を経て明治新政府を成立させた。
sen.e: After the Boshin War between the anti-Shogunate faction and the former Shogunate force, the New Meiji government came into existence.
After the Boshin War between the anti-Shogunate faction and the former Shogunate force, the New Meiji government came into existence.
After the Boshin War between the anti-Shogunate faction and the former Shogunate force, the New Meiji government came into existence.

sen.j: 1868年3月に五箇条の御誓文によって新しい政治方針を示し、同年9月には年号を明治と改めた（改元は同年1月1日に遡って適用）。
sen.e: In March 1868, the emperor announced the Charter Oath of Five Articles which laid out the new political principles and, in September of the same year, the era name was changed to Meiji (while the change of era name retroactively became effective as of January 1 of that year by the lunar calendar).

In March 1868, the emperor announced the Charter Oath of Five Articles which laid out the new political principles and, in September of the same year, the era name was changed to Meiji (while the change of era name retroactively became effective as of January 1 of that year by the lunar calendar).

sen.j: 新政府は欧米列強の軍事的・経済的圧力に対抗するために、天皇を中心とした中央集権国家の構築を目指した。
sen.e: To counter the military and economic pressure from Western powerful countries, the new government aspired to build a country with centralized government with the emperor playing the leading part.
To counter the military and economic pressure from Western powerful countries, the new government aspired to build a country with a centralized government where the emperor played a leading part.
To counter the military and economic pressure from Western powerful countries, the new government aspired to build a country with a centralized government where the emperor played a leading part.

sen.j: 新政府は、には各藩に版籍奉還を命令し、には、廃藩置県を行った。
sen.e: The new government ordered every domain to return lands and people to the emperor whereby abolishing feudal domains and establishing prefectures.
The new government ordered every domain to return lands and people to the emperor thereby abolishing feudal domains and establishing prefectures.
The new government ordered every domain to return lands and people to the emperor thereby abolishing feudal domains and establishing prefectures.

sen.j: 地租改正によって従来の米年貢を廃止し、金納地租に代えて財政基盤とした。
sen.e: The previous annual rice tax was abolished and replaced by money payment of land-tax with implementation of the land-tax reform to secure fiscal base.
The previous annual rice tax was abolished and replaced by money payment of land-tax with implementation of the land-tax reform to secure a fiscal base.
The previous annual rice tax was abolished and replaced by money payment of land-tax with implementation of the land-tax reform to secure a fiscal base.

sen.j: 国民には、江戸時代の自由の制限をなくし、身分の撤廃を行い四民平等とし、日本全国の行き来の自由を認め、職業の選択の自由や、散髪帯刀の自由など様々なことを改革していった。
sen.e: With regard to the citizens, the government lifted various restrictions on freedom existed during the Edo Period whereby the social standing system was abolished to be replaced by the equality of all people and the other various reforms such as freedom to travel across the country, freedom to choose occupations, freedom to have closely cut hair and freedom to carry a sword in belt became effective.

With regard to the citizens, the government lifted various restrictions on freedoms that existed during the Edo Period whereby the social standing system was abolished and replaced by one that made all people equal, as well as various other reforms such as freedom to travel across the country, freedom to choose occupations, freedom to have closely cut hair and freedom to carry a sword in belt.

With regard to the citizens, the government lifted various restrictions on freedoms that existed during the Edo period whereby the social standing system was abolished and replaced by one that made all people equal, as well as various other reforms such as freedom to travel across the country, freedom to choose occupations, freedom to have closely cut hair and freedom to carry a sword in belt.

sen.j: また、新政府は欧米列強の桎梏から脱出する為、富国強兵を国の重要政策とした。
sen.e: Additionally, to break away from fetters of Western powerful countries, the new government forged ahead to increase wealth of the country and to build up the military might that were recognized as the important political agenda of the time.

Additionally, to break away from the fetters of powerful Western countries, the new government forged ahead to increase the wealth of the country and build up the military might that was recognized as an important political agenda of the time.

Additionally, to break away from the fetters of powerful Western countries, the new government forged ahead to increase the wealth of the country and build up the military might that was recognized as an important political agenda of the time.

sen.j: このため、郵便制度の整備、鉄道の敷設、輸出産業の育成（一例が富岡製糸場）を行い（殖産興業）、徴兵制を実施した（戸主は徴兵を免除されたので、主に戸主以外の次三男層や貧農層の子弟が兵役を担った為、血税一揆が起きた）。
sen.e: In light of the above, the government put the postal service in place, constructed the railway system, developed export industries (with an example being Tomioka Seishi-jo (Tomioka Silk Mill)) (encouragement of new industry) and implemented conscription (which, since the household head was exempt from this legislation and the other sons of the family or male members of the poor peasant class were drafted into military service, caused the blood tax revolt (anti-conscription revolt)).

In light of the above, the government put the postal service in place, constructed the railway system, developed export industries (with an example being Tomioka Seishi-jo (Tomioka Silk Mill)) (encouragement of new industry) and implemented conscription (which, since the household head was exempt from this legislation and the other sons of the family or male members of the poor peasant class were drafted into military service, caused the blood tax revolt (anti-conscription revolt)).

sen.j: 征韓論をめぐって、強硬派の江藤新平・西郷隆盛・副島種臣・板垣退助・後藤象二郎の5人は大久保利通・岩倉具視らと対立し参議を辞任した（明治六年政変）。
sen.e: Colliding with Toshimichi OKUBO, Tomomi IWAKURA and their sympathizers over Seikanron (debate on subjugation of Korea), the 5 hardliners such as Shinpei ETO, Takamori SAIGO, Taneomi SOEJIMA, Taisuke ITAGAKI and Shojiro GOTO resigned from the post of Sangi (councilor) (Meiji roku-nen no Seihen (Political Upheaval of 1873)).

Colliding with Toshimichi OKUBO, Tomomi IWAKURA and their sympathizers over Seikanron (debate on subjugation of Korea), the 5 hardliners such as Shinpei ETO, Takamori SAIGO, Taneomi SOEJIMA, Taisuke ITAGAKI and Shojiro GOTO resigned from the post of Sangi (councilor) (Meiji roku-nen no Seihen (Political Upheaval of 1873)).

sen.j: その結果、大久保利通の独裁体制が確立することとなった。
sen.e: As a result, the dictatorship of Toshimichi OKUBO became established.
As a result, the dictatorship of Toshimichi OKUBO became established.

sen.j: 一方、下野した5人の参議は以下の行動を取った。
sen.e: In the meantime, those 5 former councilors took the following actions.
In the meantime, those 5 former councilors took the following actions.

sen.j: 西郷隆盛は故郷鹿児島に戻り、私学校を建設した。
sen.e: Takamori SAIGO returned to his hometown Kagoshima and built Shigakko (school mainly for warriors).
Takamori SAIGO returned to his hometown Kagoshima and built Shigakko (school mainly for warriors).
Takamori SAIGO returned to his hometown Kagoshima and built Shigakko (school mainly for warriors).

sen.j: また、板垣、後藤、江藤、副島らは、に民選議院設立建白書を政府に提出して有司専制を批判し、議会開設を主な要求とする自由民権運動の嚆矢となった。
sen.e: Itagaki, Goto, Eto, Soejima and their sympathizers presented an opinion paper on establishing democratically elected parliament that criticized Yushi Sensei (despotism by domain-dominated government) to the government starting the Movement for Liberty and People's Right of which the establishment of the National Diet was the main demand.

sen.j: その後、江藤は故郷の佐賀に戻り、明治維新によって特権を失った不平士族をも巻き込んで佐賀の乱を起こしたが鎮圧された。
sen.e: Eto subsequently returned to his hometown Saga and rose in revolt known as the Saga War involving the discontented local warrior class who had lost their special privileges due to the Meiji Restoration but was repressed.

Eto subsequently returned to his hometown Saga and rose in revolt known as the Saga War involving the malcontent local warrior class who had lost their special privileges due to the Meiji Restoration, but was subsequently repressed.

sen.j: 政権を掌握した大久保は、不平士族の不満を抑えることは困難であることを悟る。
sen.e: Seizing control of the government, Okubo recognized that it would be difficult to contain dissatisfaction of the discontented warrior class.

sen.j: そこで、琉球漁民が台湾の地元民に殺害されたことを理由に、、台湾出兵を行い（その結果、木戸孝允は下野した）、更に翌江華島事件を引き起こし朝鮮に日朝修好条規を締結させた。
sen.e: On the grounds of an incident in which some Ryukyu fishermen were murdered by the local residents of Taiwan, Okubo subsequently carried out the Taiwan expedition (which resulted in the resignation of Takayoshi KIDO) and, further, set off the Ganghwa Island incident to make the Korean government sign Japanese-Korea Treaty of Amity.
sen.cmt: 翌江華島事件を引き起こし － 「翌」の後が抜けています。一原文一訳文例外対処
sen.e: On the grounds of an incident in which some Ryukyu fishermen were murdered by the local residents of Taiwan, Okubo subsequently carried out the Taiwan expedition (which resulted in the resignation of Takayoshi KIDO) and, further, set off the Ganghwa Island incident to make the Korean government sign the Japanese-Korea Treaty of Amity.

sen.j: 加えて、下野した木戸や自由民権運動を率いている板垣らを牽制、懐柔するため、に大阪会議を開催し、立憲政体の詔書を発布した。
sen.e: Additionally, to warn and to conciliate Kido who resigned from the post of councilor, Itagaki who was leading Jiyu Minken Undo (the Movement for Liberty and People's Right) and their sympathizers, Okubo held the Osaka Conference to proclaim the imperial edict on the constitutional system of government.

sen.j: これにより、立法機関である元老院 (日本)、司法機関である大審院、地方官会議を開催することを決めた。
sen.e: According to the said imperial edict, Okubo decided to organize the legislative body Genroin (the Senatus) (Japan), the judicial branch Daishin-in (Predecessor of the Supreme Court of Japan) and local administrative assemblies.

sen.j: 一方、讒謗律、新聞紙条例で言論規制を行った。
sen.e: In the meantime, suppression of free speech came into effect with implemention of Zamboritsu (the Defamation Law) and Shinbunshi Jorei (Press Regulations).
In the meantime, suppression of free speech came into effect with implemention of Zamboritsu (the Defamation Law) and Shinbunshi Jorei (Press Regulations).

sen.j: 内政面では、大久保はに内務省 (日本)を設置し、殖産興業を後押しした。
sen.e: Back home, Okubo installed the Ministry of Interior (Japan) and supported encouragement of new industry.

sen.j: また、明治政府の財政難の原因となる不労所得者である士族の特権（秩禄、賞典禄）を削減したり（秩禄処分）、廃刀令を出したりした。
sen.e: Okubo, additionally, implemented Chitsuroku-shobun (Abolition Measure of Hereditary Stipend) reducing special privileges (such as Chiroku (hereditary stipend) and Shotenroku, (bonus)) of the warrior class receiving unearned income who would contribute to economic difficulties for the Meiji Government and issued a decree banning the wearing of swords.

sen.j: 相次ぐ改革により不平士族は反発、佐賀の乱を皮切りに、神風連の乱、秋月の乱、萩の乱が起きた。
sen.e: The discontented warrior class objected the continued reformative measures and starting with the Saga War, the Shimpuren-no-ran War (turmoil of Shimpuren, dissatisfied warrior group), the Akizuki-no-ran War (the turmoil of Akizuki), and the Hagi-no-ran War (turmoil of dissatisfied warriors at Hagi) broke out.

sen.j: 最後に西郷隆盛が挙兵した（西南戦争）がいずれも政府により鎮圧された。
sen.e: Takamori SAIGO ultimately raised an army (the Seinan War) following the foregoing wars but all of them were subdued by the government.

sen.j: 西郷の死により、武力による政府転覆ではなく、言論による政府批判へと時代は変わっていく。
sen.e: After the death of Saigo, times will change from the days of overthrowing the government by force of arms to the days of criticizing the government by speech.
After the death of Saigo, times changed from the days of overthrowing the government by force of arms to an era where government could be criticized through freedom of speech.

sen.j: その後、、大久保利通は暗殺され（紀尾井坂の変）、前年の西南戦争のさなかに木戸孝允も病没した為、明治新政府は、伊藤博文、大隈重信を中心に運営されることとなる。
sen.e: Due to the facts that Toshimichi OKUBO was subsequently assassinated (during the Kioizaka Incident) and Takayoshi KIDO died of illness in the midst of the Seinan War a year earlier, Hirobumi ITO and Shigenobu OKUMA accordingly became the central figures in running the Meiji Government.

sen.j: 自由民権運動の発展に対し、、開拓使官有物払下げ事件に端を発した明治十四年の政変で、伊藤博文は即時国会開設を唱えていた急進派の大隈重信一派を政府から追放する。
sen.e: To address the growing Movement for Liberty and People's Right, during the political coup of 1881 triggered by the incident in which the Hokkaido Development Commissioner disposed of state-owned articles, Hirobumi ITO drove out the left-wing faction under the leadership of Shigenobu OKUMA that was calling for immediate establishment of the Diet.

sen.j: その一方、「国会開設の詔勅」を発し、に議会を開設することを国民に約束した。
sen.e: Meanwhile, the Imperial Edict for Establishing a Diet was issued and Ito made a commitment to citizens to inaugurate the Diet.

sen.j: その結果、明治政府から追放されることとなった板垣退助は自由党を、大隈重信は立憲改進党を結成し、来る国会開設の準備を図ろうとした。
sen.e: As a result, Taisuke ITAGAKI and Shigenobu OKUMA who came to be purged from the Meiji Government formed the Liberal Party and the Constitutional Progressive Party, respectively, in preparations for the coming inauguration of the Imperial Diet.

sen.j: また、大隈重信失脚後、経済政策面で実権を掌握したのが薩摩藩出身の松方正義であった（詳細は松方デフレを参照）。
sen.e: Additionally, after the downfall of Shigenobu OKUMA, it was Masayoshi MATSUKATA from the Satsuma Clan who seized real power on economic policy (for details of which, Matsukata Deflation should be referenced).

sen.j: 松方デフレにより、農民層は貧困することになり、これに自由民権運動が連動、に秩父事件が発生した（自由民権運動の先鋭化）。
sen.e: Peasantry suffered poverty due to the Matsukata Deflation which in conjunction with the Freedom and People's Rights Movement caused the Chichibu Incident (Radicalization of the Freedom and People's Rights Movement).

sen.e: With the subsequent abolishment of the Dajokan (Great Council of State) system in 1885, the cabinet system Was implemented and Hirobumi ITO was installed as the founding Prime Minister of Japan.

sen.e: Hirobumi ITO, working with Kowashi INOUE, Miyoji ITO, Kentaro KANEKO, Roesler and the other concerned parties, began preparations for the establishment of the constitution and installed Sumitsu-in (Privy Council) (Japan).

sen.j: そして、、黒田清隆内閣の時、君主権が強いプロイセン憲法を模倣した大日本帝国憲法が明治天皇から臣下に授ける形で制定された（欽定憲法）。
sen.e: During times of the cabinet of Kiyotaka KURODA, the Constitution of the Empire of Japan modeling after the Prussian constitution which stresses royal prerogative was established in a manner that Emperor Meiji bestowed it on his subjects (a constitution enacted by the emperor).

sen.j: この憲法に対する当時の評価は高く、国内では「聞きしにまさる良憲法」（高田早苗）などと民権派からの絶賛もあった。
sen.e: This constitution received high acclaim at the time and, within the country, there was a raving comment of the People's Rights sector as 'a constitution that exceeded one's expectations in its excellence' (as per Sanae TAKADA).

sen.e: While there were some reservations regarding the actual operational abilities, the constitution received high acclaim from intellectuals in U. S. and European countries (with a specific example being Erwin von Bälz) in terms of its contents.

Contents of the Constitution of the Empire of Japan

sen.j: 同憲法は、天皇は、第三条で神聖不可侵と規定され、第四条で統治権を総攬する元首と規定された。
sen.e: Pursuant to Article 3 of this Constitution, it prescribed that the Emperor as sacred and inviolable and pursuant to Article 4 of same, it defined the Emperor as the head of the state having complete control of sovereignty.

Pursuant to Article 3 of this Constitution, it prescribed that the Emperor was sacred and inviolable and pursuant to Article 4 of same, it defined the Emperor as the head of the state having complete control of sovereignty.

sen.j: 三権に関しては以下の通りである。
sen.e: With regard to Sanken (organization of three branches), contents are as follows:
With regard to Sanken (organization of three branches), contents are as follows:

sen.j: 第一に、立法であるが天皇は第五条において帝国議会の協賛を以って行使すると規定された。
sen.e: First of all, with regard to legislation, pursuant to Article 5, it stipulated that the Emperor exercised the legislative power with the consent of the Imperial Diet.
First of all, with regard to legislation, pursuant to Article 5, it stipulated that the Emperor exercised the legislative power with the consent of the Imperial Diet.
First of all, with regard to legislation, pursuant to Article 5, it stipulated that the Emperor exercised the legislative power with the consent of the Imperial Diet.

sen.j: しかしその職務は概ね、法律を裁可することのみであり、またその裁可には国務大臣の副署が必要とされた。
sen.e: The Emperor's job duties, however, were generally limited to give Imperial sanction to laws which required the countersignature of the Minister of State.
The Emperor's job duties, however, were generally limited to give Imperial sanction to laws which required the countersignature of the Minister of State.
The Emperor's job duties, however, were generally limited to give Imperial sanction to laws which required the countersignature of the Minister of State.

sen.j: つまり、大臣副署がなければその法律は無効であり、さらに天皇が裁可を拒むことは形式上可能であっても、事実上は不可能であった。
sen.e: In other words, unless countersigned by the Minister of State, the law was invalid and, further, while it was formally possible for the emperor to refuse to give sanction, it was practically impossible for him to do so.

In other words, unless countersigned by the Minister of State, the law was invalid and, further, while it was formally possible for the emperor to refuse to give sanction, it was practically impossible for him to do so.

sen.j: この点は現在のイギリス国王も同じといえる。
sen.e: It can be said that the British monarch is in a similar situation in this behalf.

sen.j: また、帝国議会は選挙で選ばれる国会議員から成る衆議院と華族から成る貴族院 (日本)の二院で構成された。
sen.e: Additionally, the Imperial Diet consisted of 2 houses including the House of Representatives composed of the Members of the Diet who carried election and the House of Peers (Japan) comprised of the peerages.

sen.j: 第二に、行政であるが、後の日本国憲法と異なり連帯責任ではなく、第五五条で各国務大臣は天皇を輔弼し、個別に責任を負うものであった。
sen.e: In the second place, with regard to administration, pursuant to Article 55, unlike the subsequent Constitution of Japan which is defined as collective responsibility, it prescribed that the respective Ministers of State would give their advice to the Emperor and be responsible for it.

sen.j: 第三に司法権であるが、第五七条で天皇の名において法律により裁判所が司法権を行うものであった。
sen.e: In the third place, with respect to the judicatory power, pursuant to Article 57, it was stipulated to be exercised by the Courts of Law according to law, in the name of the Emperor.

sen.j: 同憲法の問題は、主なものに以下の二つが挙げられる。
sen.e: There are 2 major problems with this constitution that include the following:

sen.j: 第一は、第一一条に規定されている天皇は陸海軍を統帥するという規定であった。
sen.e: First, there was a prescript in Section 11 that the Emperor had the supreme command of the Army and Navy.
First, there was a prescript in Section 11 that the Emperor had supreme command over the Army and Navy.
First, there was a prescript in Section 11 that the Emperor had supreme command over the Army and Navy.

sen.j: 内閣や帝国議会は軍部に対し直接関与できなかった（これが、後の統帥権干犯問題を引き起こすこととなる）。
sen.e: The foregoing prescript precluded the Cabinet and the Imperial Diet from involving directly with the military (which, later on, caused a political dispute over interference of the supreme command).
The foregoing prescript precluded the Cabinet and the Imperial Diet from involving directly with the military (which, later on, caused a political dispute over interference of the supreme command).

sen.j: 第二は、第二一条で規定された法律の範囲内において自由であるという臣民の権利であった（後に治安維持法などで権利の制限を行うようになる）。
sen.e: Second, it stipulated the rights of Japanese subjects that, pursuant to Article 21, they had the liberty within the limits of the law (but restrictive measures such as the Maintenance of Public Order Law subsequently came into effect to quality the rights of the subjects).

sen.j: また、黒田清隆首相は「政党の動向に左右されず、超然として公正な施策を行おうとする政府の政治姿勢（超然主義）」を示し、議会と対立した。
sen.e: Additionally, showing 'political stance of the government which aspired to take equitable measures being uninfluenced by and detached from movements of political parties,' Prime Minister Kiyotaka KURODA came into collision with the Diet.

sen.j: その後、明治22年（1889年）の大日本帝国憲法公布にともない、衆議院議員選挙法が公布され、直接国税15円以上を納税した25歳以上の男子のみ（当時の全人口の1.1%）に選挙権を与えた制限選挙を実施し、に最初の帝国議会（第一議会）が開会された。
sen.e: Afterwards, in conjunction with proclamation of the Constitution of the Empire of Japan in 1889, the Election Law of the Member of the House of Representatives was issued whereby implementing limited election allowing male subjects who directly paid 15 yen or more in general tax and who were over 25 of age (that accounted for approximately 1.1% of the total population of Japan at the time) to vote and, on November 25, 1890, the inaugural Imperial Diet (the first parliamentary session) convened.

sen.j: 植民地化されずに自力で近代化への改革をなした日本は、明治27年（1894年）にはイギリスと条約改正を成し遂げ、これを皮切りに江戸時代末期以来の不平等条約の解消を進めた。
sen.e: Successfully reforming itself to a modern nation without becoming a colony of another country, in 1894, Japan accomplished a treaty revision with England which started the process of terminating an unequal treaty that had existed since the end of the Edo Period.

sen.e: Negotiations conducted by Foreign Minister Kaoru INOUE (1882 - 1888) : Measures to Europeanize such as construction of Rokumeikan Hall and installment of judges from foreign countries at the court were proposed but due to objections raised by Gustave Emile BOISSONADE, Tateki TANI and the nationalist group in addition to the unfortunate handling of the Normanton Incident, Inoue resigned.

sen.j: 日本は、明治15年(1882年)の壬午軍乱、明治17年(1884年)の甲申事変を契機に朝鮮を巡り、清と対立し、甲午農民戦争を契機に、明治27年(1894年)に日清戦争が勃発した。
sen.e: The subsequent Imo Incident and the Gapsin Coup triggered hostility over Korea between Japan and China and, touched off by the subsequent Donghak Peasant Revolution, the Sino-Japanese War began.

sen.j: 当時の国力では財力、軍艦、装備、兵数すべてにおいて清の方が優位であったが士気と訓練度で勝った日本は勝利し、下関条約によって以下の内容を清に認めさせた。
sen.e: China had stronger national power in all aspects including wealth, warships, arms and the number of soldiers but Japan with higher morale and better training won whereby obtaining the agreement of China on the following conditions by signing the Treaty of Shimonoseki:

sen.j: 下関条約の結果、清の朝鮮に対する宗主権は否定され、ここに東アジアの国際秩序であった冊封体制は終焉を迎えた（李氏朝鮮は大韓帝国として独立した）。
sen.e: As a result of the Treaty of Shimonoseki, China's suzerainty over Korea was renounced whereby the traditional tributary system which was the international order in East Asia came to an end (and the Yi Dynasty Korea attained independence as the Korean Empire).

sen.e: Due to the Triple Intervention of Russia, France and Germany, however, Liaodong Peninsula was returned to China (in exchange for 30 million teal in compensation paid to Japan) that consequently was perceived as an insult and fueled retaliatory sentiment among Japanese people (as in a proverb it was struggling against difficulties for the sake of vengeance).

sen.e: As a result of this war, Japan joined the ranks of powerful countries gaining recognition from Western mighty nations.

sen.e: In the meantime, the defeat of China that was dubbed as 'the sleeping lion' resulted in accelerating activities of the various powerful countries aiming to colonize the Chinese continent.

sen.e: Additionally, the result of the Sino-Japanese War also had economic impact with the war reparations serving as the source of implementing the gold standard system and providing funds for building (and establishing) the Yahata Iron Factory.

sen.e: After the Sino-Japanese War ended, the Russian Empire put pressure on China making Lushun in Liaodong Peninsula and Dalian City the leased territory of Russia.

sen.j: 日本はロシアの動きを牽制すべく、には、日英同盟を締結した。
sen.e: In, to put a brake on the Russian movement, Japan and England signed the Anglo-Japanese Alliance.
To slow the Russian movement, Japan and England signed the Anglo-Japanese Alliance.

sen.j: 当時世界第一の大帝国で「栄光ある孤立」を貫いていたイギリスが初めて同盟を締結したということと、アジアの新興国家である日本が相手ということから世界の注目を受けた。
sen.e: This alliance attracted considerable attention worldwide because England, the greatest empire on earth of the time that had previously adhered to the principle of 'Splendid Isolation,' entered into an alliance for the very first time and also because the other party was Japan that was an emerging country in Asia.

sen.e: Coming ashore in Liaodong Peninsula, the Japanese army succeeded by a narrow margin to force the Russian army with an overwhelming material superiority to back off during the siege of Lushun and the Battle of Mukden.

sen.e: Russia still sustained the army but, due to the fact that much of the sea power had been lost and a revolutionary movement was developing within the country, it leaned towards making peace with Japan.

sen.j: 日露戦争における日本の勝利は、白色人種の大国に対する有色人種の小国の、また絶対主義国家に対する立憲君主国家の勝利であり、世界史上の意義も大きかった。
sen.e: Japan's winning the Russo-Japanese War was significant in the course of world history because it was a victory of a small colored country over a big white country as well as a triumph of a constitutional monarchy over a country under an absolutistic ruler.

sen.e: Later, in July, the second administration of the Katsura Cabinet approved the annexation of Korea and when Ito arrived in Harbin during his visit to Manchuria for a talk with the Russian Empire, he was assassinated by Ahn Jung-geun who was an activist for the independence of the Korean Empire.

Later, in July, the second administration of the Katsura Cabinet approved the annexation of Korea and when Ito arrived in Harbin on October 26 during his visit to Manchuria for a talk with the Russian Empire, he was assassinated by Ahn Jung-geun who was an activist for the independence of the Korean Empire.

sen.j: 大国ロシアに対して戦勝を記録したことは、諸外国にも反響を与えたが、嘉永年間以来の黒船の衝撃と、その後目指した西欧列強に並ぶ近代国家づくりの目標は一応達成されたとする説もある。
sen.e: Japan's victory over the major power Russia made an impact abroad but there was an opinion that its objective to develop itself to become a modern nation comparable to Western powerful countries after the earth-shattering visit by Kurofune during the Kaei era (1848-1854) was accomplished at the least.

sen.j: その後第一次世界大戦の講和により完成したヴェルサイユ条約の世界で、に設立された国際連盟に常任理事国として参加し、日本は明治維新から約50年という速さで列強国のひとつに数えられることになった。
sen.e: Later, as a result of the Treaty of Versailles signed to conclude the peace process after the World War I, the League of Nations was founded with Japan participating as a permanent member whereby It became one of the powerful countries in the world in mere fifty years or thereabouts since the Meiji Restoration.
